text: <@U0KPFAZNF> <@U0UHG4VP1> <@U0YK3KKCY> Thanks for pushing the new release of fabric-baseimage. I did try the build on Power and it works fine after tweaking the fabric.git/.baseimage-release
However as pointed out by <@U0YK3KKCY>, one of the unit-tests failed which was working earlier
Can we have the CI enabled for P and Z for fabric repo as well ? This should help us get attention of such arch specific changes that might break the build on another arch.
I see we have it enabled for fabric-baseimage repo.
<@U11NUTP4L> you're asking to have jobs like fabric-verify-x86_64 created for power and z?
<@U11NUTP4L> that would show up here for instance: <https://jenkins.hyperledger.org/view/fabric/>
<@U0UHG4VP1> right. I was looking at having such verify builds enabled for P and Z as well.
Currently such verify builds are happening on all 3 archs (x86_64, ppc64le and s390x) for fabric-baseimage repo, seen @ <https://jenkins.hyperledger.org/view/fabric-baseimage/>
yes, I see
srirama_sharma: I will try to get this CI work done today. Who would I talk to about debugging it in seven or eight hours when I wake up again? :slightly_smiling_face:

<@U11NUTP4L>: We have `verify` and `merge` jobs created for Power and Z but we have disabled  them as we were having unit-tests failures and also we are having very limited number of build resources (few slave machines: for Power we have 5 nodes and Z we have 2) in Jenkins..

ry: we have verify and merge jobs for power and z here <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/gitweb?p=ci-management.git;a=tree;f=jjb/fabric;h=d8259004e333d07adf6903f10f21b584a1eb33f2;hb=refs/heads/master>
ramesh: you're supposed to be on vacation!
yes <@U0UHG4VP1>
I added you to two CRs. I'm waiting for my co-workers to wake up and review <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/2399/9> before I merge <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/3083/2>
ok looking them now

<@U11HH3P7Y> Yes. I know you had set it up before for fabric-baseimage and for fabric it wasn’t as the build itself was failing due to Java SHIM issue. Now that build is taken care of can we have it enabled. ?
But yes. the unit-test are failing now due to the CR pointed by <@U0YK3KKCY> earlier

<@U0UHG4VP1> you have a good sleep :slightly_smiling_face:. 8 Hrs from now, you could either still see me online or by that time <@U0YK3KKCY> might be there to check anything specific to arch changes. we both are more or less seeing same issues (and same fixes too ) for P and Z respectively
<@U0UHG4VP1>, <@U11NUTP4L> note that we can't turn on those P/Z jobs until the CR that updates baseimage to v0.2.2 is merged
(IIUC)
<@U0KPFAZNF> Yes. you are right
i anticipate we will have problems with any older CRs that havent rebased too
so that will need to be managed
suggest making P/Z an advisory vote during the transition
once everyone is rebased on top of the v0.2.2 cut-point, we can enable full vote
Sounds okay to me. With the advisory vote, even if the verify jobs fail, we will know why it is failing - either requiring a rebase or due to any other issue due to arch difference.
right, and then once we stablize things so X/P/Z are expected to collectively pass, we can turn on the verification to ensure it continues to be that way moving forward

<@U11HH3P7Y> experiencing unit-test failures for p and z is a good sign in terms on ensuring that the codebase works for all platforms.  When the unit-tests were disabled, p and z were in "catch up" mode (putting in patches to resolved platform-based issues) in an attempt to get to a point where the unit-tests could then be re-enabled.  i can somewhat understand disabling due to lack of minions... if this is the case then how many minions are required?

i will write up a jira issue on the latest issue re; errors unit-test failing for p and z.  if i checkout the commit before the error framework commit was put in, all tests pass.  when i checkout the error framework commit, the errors test fails.

root@p880-lpar7:~/git/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric# git checkout ae9f2f2
ae9f2f2 [FAB-816] Clean multichain integration interfaces ===> PASS

root@p880-lpar7:~/git/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric# git checkout 2dc82e0
2dc82e0 Enhance and begin using error handling framework ===> FAIL
<@U0KPFAZNF> more ignorance on my part... the term "advisory vote"... is this a gerrit term?
if we are resource constrained on P/Z, suggest considering a pipeline....e.g. only commits that pass the x86 tier move on to test on P/Z
it will reduce the number of jobs that P/Z need to handle, at a loss of parallelism
need to step away, bbiab

<@U0KPFAZNF> the ppc64le base image with tag - ppc64le-0.0.11 that was pushed few days back to <https://hub.docker.com/r/hyperledger/fabric-baseimage/> is having issues. It is missing out all the rocksdb header files. Hence with this docker image, fabric build from v0.6 branch is failing now. Build works fine if I force a latest baseimage build from source by editing `images/base/release` to 0.0.12. 

```
root@p006vm40:~/git/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric# docker run -it hyperledger/fabric-baseimage:ppc64le-0.0.11 
root@51db3bf8e72b:/# find / -name rocksdb
root@51db3bf8e72b:/# 
root@51db3bf8e72b:/# exit
exit
root@p006vm40:~/git/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric# git status
On branch v0.6
Your branch is up-to-date with 'origin/v0.6'.
Changes not staged for commit:
  (use "git add <file>..." to update what will be committed)
  (use "git checkout -- <file>..." to discard changes in working directory)

	modified:   images/base/release

Untracked files:
  (use "git add <file>..." to include in what will be committed)

	nohup.out

no changes added to commit (use "git add" and/or "git commit -a")
root@p006vm40:~/git/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric# git diff
diff --git a/images/base/release b/images/base/release
index 2cfabea..8cbf02c 100644
--- a/images/base/release
+++ b/images/base/release
@@ -1 +1 @@
-0.0.11
+0.0.12
root@p006vm40:~/git/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric# docker run -it hyperledger/fabric-baseimage:latest 
root@766aa88cfb29:/# find / -name rocksdb
/usr/local/include/rocksdb
root@766aa88cfb29:/# ls /usr/local/include/rocksdb/
c.h                     db.h                flush_block_policy.h  memtablerep.h     rate_limiter.h     statistics.h        types.h
cache.h                 db_dump_tool.h      immutable_options.h   merge_operator.h  slice.h            status.h            universal_compaction.h
compaction_filter.h     delete_scheduler.h  iostats_context.h     metadata.h        slice_transform.h  table.h             utilities
compaction_job_stats.h  env.h               iterator.h            options.h         snapshot.h         table_properties.h  version.h
comparator.h            experimental.h      ldb_tool.h            perf_context.h    sst_dump_tool.h    thread_status.h     write_batch.h
convenience.h           filter_policy.h     listener.h            perf_level.h      sst_file_writer.h  transaction_log.h   write_batch_base.h
root@766aa88cfb29:/#
```
<@U0KPFAZNF> - This problem is for the fabric baseimage I uploaded for V0.6 recently. I will upload the new one soon.
<@U12V3D2P2> can you provide an overview as to how you built the v0.0.11 that is published now?
in theory, it should have been similar to the process that <@U11NUTP4L> just tried manually that worked
<@U0KPFAZNF> usually it's the same process that Srirama tried, but this time it could be that the tag was used for  an image that was previously built from fabric baseimage repo
not following: building from a tag shouldnt cause a misfire in the build, unless the tag happens to point to code that contains a flaw or missing logic
are we thinking there were fixes that went into v0.6 since the v0.0.11 image was tagged?
that could explain it
but rocksdb missing is fairly fundamental, that has been in the image since we started building baseimage
<@U0KPFAZNF> probably by tag Smita meant she did docker tag to an image that was previously built using fabric-baseimage repo (which now has your patch which removed rocksdb entirely)
so it was more a docker tag and docker push issue than the build.
Yes
correct me <@U12V3D2P2> if my guess is wrong
ok, im confused a bit
to be clear: to build "v0.0.11", we should technically be building from the point in time in which v0.0.11 was cut originally
now, normally the solution would be to reference a git-tag, but we didnt have the ability to tag git back then
so, no tag exists, but a commit-sha should
in this case, it would be in the fabric.git/v0.6 branch, since it predates the split to the baseimage.git erpo
IIUC, whats happening now is we built ppc-0.0.11 from something newer than this
I guess so. that the docker base image built from fabric-baseimage repo was tagged to be v0.0.11 given that fabric-baseimage repo now doesn’t have anything related to rocksdb.
if that is the case, that is the problem
the baseimage for v0.6 needs to be built from the v0.6 branch in fabric.git
for v0.6, this is in images/base
Yes, that's what I built just now
otherwise, we will pick up a whole bunch of other changes that are probably not suitable for v0.6 consumption
(like dropping rocksdb for instance, but there are others too: the version of golang and protobufs come to mind)
this is the commit that should be tagged "v0.0.11": 4fa1360b0967abca65665235e861b400cc1425d5

my recommendation is we either a) make a build for ppc from 4fa1360b0967abca65665235e861b400cc1425d5, or b) if that wont work, we patch the v0.6 branch with whatever we need, and cut a v0.0.12 for all platforms
this will maintain coherence with the version
anything else is asking for trouble :wink:
im sorry <@U12V3D2P2>, I should have guided you more closely before
That's fine <@U0KPFAZNF>, thanks for being patient.
i assumed this is what you did, but I can see in retrospect this wasnt obvious
<@U12V3D2P2> let me know if commit 4fa1360b09 produces a suitable baseimage container...if so, we can overwrite the ppc-0.0.11 that is published and be done with it
<@U0KPFAZNF> there is no further changes required on v0.6 branch to have it built on ppc64le.  so option (b) is not required
ok, perfect
thats the ideal situation
Can I upload the new baseimage again to my private repo from which you can copy to Hyperledger community with 0.0.11 tag?
yep, just let me know when its ready
it only takes two seconds to pull/re-push once you get there
Wouldn’t it be right if we just do git checkout v0.6 and build the baseimage and push it as v0.0.11 ?
maybe not that fast, but long story short, its virtually little work for me
<@U11NUTP4L> i think in this case, v0.6/HEAD and commit 4fa1360b09 would effectively be equivalent, yes
the reason why I ask is, the recent fix c1fc31f6f172f17a58ebe23ad2125b20021183aa is required to build v0.6
its not really a good practice to assume that, but I think in this case, this is true
oh
yes. I completely agreee
let me look at the patch
the patch is my patch to comment the java SHIM commenting patch
this is in the v0.6 branch
yes. It is in both v0.6 and master
<@U0KPFAZNF|ghaskins> uploaded a file: <https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/ghaskins/F3CCRMP9A/-.sh|Untitled>

file.name: -.sh
file.title: Untitled
file.preview_highlight:
$ git branch -r --contains c1fc31f6f172f
  gerrit/v0.6

text: yep
I'm a little apprehensive to suggest we should tag something v0.0.11 which is based on different code
i realize its a bit of a gray area considering the conditionals for x86 effectively make the patch a no-op
wait, let me confirm that this did in fact come after the original cut
ah, yep, last patch committed, heh
I can understand why you are feeling so. So better option would be as you suggested earlier, cut a new release of v0.0.12 for base image from the top of the branch v0.6
just a thought!
its certainly the more pure approach, though its a PITA for me
:slightly_smiling_face:
but PITA should not influence what is right
but yeah, i need to cut a v0.2.2 for mainline anyway
is there anyway how we could help on that to make it a lesser pain for you ?
lets roll up a new release for both, do it right
<@U0UHG4VP1>: what is the status of sandbox + docker-credentials?
<https://hub.docker.com/r/bsmita/fabric-baseimage/tags/> , pushed 0.0.11 to that repo
<@U0YK3KKCY> <@U11NUTP4L> what is the state of jenkins builders for P+Z?
currently, i have two z minions that are available
i am working to get several more into the pipline
IIRC, the only way to do a jenkins based publication of v0.6 baseimage is via sandbox job
<@U0KPFAZNF> we have 5 build nodes for P so should be good for now (until we enable CI for fabric repo after updating the baseimage version to 0.2.2)
the z minions were used for fabric-baseimage builds
<@U12V3D2P2> ty, im going to try to have the pipeline do it first
only because that helps ensure consistency, etc
if that fails, we can fall back on your custom build
Sure
<@U0YK3KKCY> ty...by the way, to your earlier question "advisory vote" isnt a gerrit thing per se
k
i just made it up to describe a vote that doesnt impact mergability, like how we run behave today
the output is interesting, but not gating acceptance criteria
ah okay
(as opposed to not running it at all, or letting it block acceptance)
btw, i chatted with the author of the patch that broke unit test for p and z.  he'll submit a fix within a day or so.
thanks for the explanation
cool, which one was it?
2dc82e0 Enhance and begin using error handling framework
<https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/2685/>
interesting, ill have to look to understand why it was $arch sensitive
i opened an issue on it <https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-1311>
Yeah. At the outset the CR didn’t appear to be arch sensitive to me too
this line stood out in the stack trace...
unit-tests_1  | /opt/go/src/runtime/asm_amd64.s:2087 runtime.goexit
:slightly_smiling_face:
ah, ouch
that would do it
yep
i dont yet understand how that became entangled here, but I can certainly understand the result
i have no clue. i'm not a go expert
yeah, I would have thought that would generally be managed by the go ecosystem
obviously something went awry
<@U0KPFAZNF> why do we need to publish to dockerhub from staging? It looks like the jobs on production worked for pushing to dockerhub
if I had to guess, its related to docker
<@U0UHG4VP1>: well, the short answer is: its not a hard requirement, I am open...however, I do not believe a job exists on the production side which was design to handle the v0.6 deployment
ah I understand.
so, I think sandbox is the path of least resistance to get access to the $arch builders
will the 0.6 branch continue with active development?
the stuff we pushed through to production only deals with the new baseimage.git stuff
also, please note, the sandbox is now being cleaned out every week (all jobs deleted). this was supposed to be true from launch
probably not: generally people thought v0.6.1 would be the last v0.6.x release at all
but, im pretty sure we need a v0.6.2 and a v0.0.12, so maybe "just one more"
:wink:
the cleanup is no problem, this is a one-shot
or, I believe it is, heh
well, save a copy
But I see that the v0.6 branch has been marked as closed around 7 days ago
these guys may come back needing a v0.0.13, for all I know :wink:
ah, thats a problem
on both the v0.6.2 and v0.0.12 fronts
so i believe no more code changes goes in. But we can build from top of the branch right
yeah, lets just go with plan a
<@U12V3D2P2> so your "0.0.11" is basically built from v0.6/HEAD ?
Yes. and I am sure and hopeful that we wouldn’t need v0.0.13 :slightly_smiling_face:
Yes
ok, its bsmita/fabric-baseimage, right?
yes
pulling now
pushed: <https://hub.docker.com/r/hyperledger/fabric-baseimage/tags/>
give it a whirl
Thank you, will try
checked the new v0.0.11 image and am now able to build fabric from v0.6 branch successfully.
<@U0KPFAZNF> <@U12V3D2P2> Thanks
cool
ok.. time for dinner.. ttyl
<@U0KPFAZNF> Power nodes are available for build, what's the next step?
<@U12V3D2P2> scratch that, not needed any more
that was just if I needed to cut v0.0.12 from jenkins
We still need to upload peer and membersrvc images to docker hub :slightly_smiling_face:
i was going to craft a sandbox job to manually build the baseimage and submit
oh, hmmm
one problem we are going to face is the :latest snafu
for instance
<https://hub.docker.com/r/hyperledger/fabric-peer/tags/>
technically, the :latest tag that is there is totally bogus, but there are flows that are still dependent on it being there
(as I discovered when I tried to clean this up and people complained
Ok...
so, I put it back, pointing to x86_64-0.6.1-preview for now
obviously, I can only do this once :wink:
I can put ppc64le-0.6.1-preview out there, but I cant retag it :latest
you would have to qualify whether this even works and what work-arounds you might need to recommend to people to deal with
I think for now we can work with this tag
ppc64le-0.6.1 should be okay for now for both peer and membersrvc
ok, let me think about best way to get it out there
we may need an additional step of pulling ppc64le-0.6.1 and then tagging it locally to :latest
yes...you still need to keep in mind: the code still is not structured to work with pure dockerhub yet
even in mainline, technically
see FAB-678
you mean different repo for different arch making use of the way docker understands the arch ?
ok.
right now, even mainline, the only thing that "works" is building from source
though it is slightly easier to deal with in mainline, and is converging on totally turn key as part of FAB-678
we have docker compose scripts locally to pull the images with right tag based on the underlying arch
right, but that alone might not be enough
the issue is that in v0.6 and earlier, the build synthesizes baseimage:latest in a JIT fashion as part of the build
its not just a retagging, it also processes the image locally
Oh. ok
that synthesis would not occur if you simply "docker run hyperledger/fabric-peer:ppc64le-..."
the long and the short of it is: the images such as peer and membersrvc were pushed to dockerhub before the code was really ready to use that model
and then people started to rely on them being there, making it a tough situation
this is improving on several fronts, at least in master, but we arent quite there to call FAB-678 "done"
for one, the code will auto-couple versions
and for seconds, the baseimage no longer requires synthesis
there is still a gaping hole on the SDK front, but if I can ever get out from under my build/release duties, ill fix :wink:
yeah. I think I get it .. and hence the BASE_TAG being used right ?
precisely, that is the auto-couple thing
like, peer vX.Y.Z will couple to ccenv vX.Y.Z
ok
long story short: we _can_ push those tags to dockerhub, but I am not entirely sure what it buys us really
my recommendation, anyone working in v0.6 should be building from source...its really the only supported deployment model
at least now, we have build-caches for P/Z :wink:
rejoice in not needing to wait for rocksdb or protoc to compile any more :wink:
yeah. Thats quite a relief and save of time
so, all that said: if you guys really want those images up there, I have no problem with it
just not sure what it really buys us
I dont want my statements to be misconstrued as refusing to publish, that is not the case at all

If it's not too much trouble please push them, we are just making sure that the end to end build process is working and we have a version of docker images available for Power also :slightly_smiling_face:
ok, ill have to check but I dont think we have anything automated for v0.6
I think all v0.6/v0.0.11 artifacts were done either manually or via jenkins sandbox
Ok..thank you!

If you continue to see issues just retry the transaction, it should work.
k. thanks for looking into it.
+100 :slightly_smiling_face:
I'm aware of the missing credentials issue in Jenkins and am working on it
that particular issue is fixed. From this point forward, all dynamic minions will be single use only
